description:
;Popular
:American folk singer [[Bob Dylan]], {{small|(1961–)}}<ref name="PrettyFly"/> soul musician [[Gil Scott-Heron]] {{small|(1969–2011)}},<ref name="PrettyFly"/> humorist and rock musician [[Frank Zappa]] {{small|(1955–1993)}},<ref>Slaven, Neil (2009). ''Electric Don Quixote: The Definitive Story Of Frank Zappa'', Omnibus Press, {{ISBN|9780857120434}}. Quote: "Frank Zappa's often brilliant combination of irreverent humour and 'serious' music has and will continue to baffle many [...] Why does somebody who has the gift of satire and comedy waste his time composing orchestral pieces?"</ref> surreal funk musicians [[George Clinton (funk musician)|George Clinton]] {{small|(1955–)}} and [[Parliament Funkadelic]],<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Hip Hop Movement : From R&B and the Civil Rights Movement to Rap and the Hip Hop Generation|last=Rabaka|first=Reiland|publisher=Lexington Books|year=2013| isbn=9780739182437|pages=255}}</ref> hardcore punk band [[Dead Kennedys]] {{small|(1978–)}}<ref>Smith GD, Dines M, Parkinson T (2017). ''Punk Pedagogies: Music, Culture and Learning'', Routledge, p. 193, {{ISBN|9781351995801}}.</ref> grindcore band [[Anal Cunt]] {{small|(1988–2011)}},<ref name="Sociology"/> and punk rock band [[The Kominas]] {{small|(2004–)}}.<ref name="Sociology"/> 
;Avant-garde
:Musicians that combined  satire and avant-garde include [[Throbbing Gristle]] {{small| (1975–)}},<ref>{{cite book|last=Stubbs|first=David|title=Fear of Music: Why People Get Rothko But Don't Get Stockhausen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JB5l4uKJknUC&pg=PA87|year=2009|publisher=John Hunt Publishing|page=87|isbn=978-1-84694-179-5}}</ref> [[Negativland]] {{small|(1979–)}},<ref>Zimmermann, Patricia R. (2019) ''Documentary Across Platforms: Reverse Engineering Media, Place, and Politics'', Indiana University, {{ISBN|9780253043504}}. Quote: "A hybrid between an artists' collective, a punk rock band, and a satirical performance art team, Negativeland's subversive antics have helped to define interventionist art in the last two decades. They coined the term "culture jammer" in 1984."</ref> [[Culturcide]] {{small|(1980–)}},<ref>Lynskey, Dorian (2011). ''[[33 Revolutions per Minute (book)|33 Revolutions Per Minute]]'', Faber & Faber, p. 1806, {{ISBN|9780571277209}}.</ref> and the so-called ''Americana absurdum'' movement comprising [[The Monks|monks]] {{small|(1964–1967)}}, [[The Residents]] {{small|(1969–)}} especially their albums<ref>Sarig, Roni (1998). ''The Secret History of Rock: The Most Influential Bands You've Never Heard'', Billboard Books, p. 72, {{ISBN|9780823076697}}.</ref> ''[[The Third Reich 'n  Roll|The Residents Present the Third Reich and Roll]]'' (1976) and ''[[Commercial Album]]'' (1980), [[Devo|DEVO]] {{small|(1973–)}}, and [[Talking Heads]] {{small|(1975–1991)}}.<ref>Carr, Paul (editor), 2013, Frank Zappa and the And, p. 100, {{ISBN| 9781409433378}}.</ref>  Another example is a digital hardcore album ''[[Alec Empire vs. Elvis Presley]]'' (1998).<ref>{{cite journal|title=CMJ New Music Report| journal=[[CMJ New Music Report]]|date=Nov 15, 1999|issue=643|page=10}}</ref>
